Landslide Modeling and Disaster Relief. 1. Introduction

Landslides occur worldwide and are caused by various factors, including natural events such as earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and heavy rainfall, as well as human activities like deforestation, dam construction, and illegal mining. For instance, a landslide in the village of Malin, Pune, India, was attributed to heavy rainfall, although other factors like deforestation, agriculture, mining, and dam construction may have contributed to the event. These factors can have a long-term impact on soil formation and properties.

We propose to leverage data from affected landslide locations to study the underlying changes and predict potential future events based on similar patterns. Our approach aims to use conditional generative adversarial networks (cGANs) to model what an area would look like under certain conditions. For example, if there is suspicion of illegal mining in a region, a network trained to detect variations due to natural and human activities can infer the composition post-mining. This information can be used to detect and halt the activity more easily. Similarly, we can infer the best locations to plant trees and mitigate soil erosion through reforestation efforts.

We consider gathering data from six main causes of landslide occurrences: volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, deforestation, heavy rainfall, mining, and construction, as well as a positive sample – a thriving forest ecosystem.

2. Related Works

We briefly review previous landslide detection approaches and relevant deep learning architectures. Landslide modeling and detection have been a topic of interest, primarily concerned with mapping learning representations to predict landslide occurrences and regional landslide susceptibility. Existing work uses different machine learning approaches on highly localized data and specific imaging platforms. For example, Uemoto et al. processed synthetic aperture radar (SAR) data from the 2016 Kumamoto earthquake (Japan) for generating amplitude and height difference maps, which they later fused for landslide detection. Ghorbanzadeh et al. compared different machine learning approaches for landslide detection by combining optical data from the Rapid Eye satellite and topographic information at Rasuwa district (Nepal).

To the best of our knowledge, no one has yet combined data from various locations and created a common model that is location-agnostic and can be used to predict future occurrences. Inspired by ExtremeWeather, we aim to develop a model that can be applied to various locations and predict landslide occurrences based on similar patterns.
